thread.title: Merkel humiliates Theresa May over cancelled Brexit talks
thread.title_full: Merkel humiliates Theresa May over cancelled Brexit talks | Daily Mail Online

author: Matt Hunter For Mailonline
title: Merkel humiliates Theresa May over cancelled Brexit talks
text:
British officials were left red-faced when news of the schedule change came through
The German chancellor humiliated Theresa May when she cancelled a planned sitdown meeting at the EU summit in Malta.
British officials were left red-faced when news of the schedule change came through.
Mrs May had to settle for a brief walk and talk with Angela Merkel in the capital, Valetta.
Following the chat the prime minister flew home after lunch whilst EU leaders continued discussions on the impact of Brexit.
The short meeting saw the chancellor criticise Mrs May for wooing firms with low taxes, adding there was no need for 'a race for the lowest corporation taxes'.
Hopes that Britain could bridge communications between the US and EU, following Mrs May's meetings with president Trump, were put under pressure by Francois Hollande.
The meeting between Mrs May and the chancellor was meant to the highlight of the day of talks.
Officially the day's talks between the EU leaders was on the refugee crisis but there was focus on Trump's presidency and Brexit.
Downing Street said 'everything' was covered in the walk and talk, and there was 'no need' for a further meeting, the Guardian reported.
The French president said it was not down to 'the UK or any other to represent Europe' for the the US.
Mrs May's case was backed by her winning Trump's '100 per cent commitment' to NATO.
President Hollande said: 'There are many countries which need to think about the fact that their future is first and foremost within the EU, rather than imagining some bilateral relationship with the US.'
'They must understand that there is no future with Trump if it is not a common position. What matters is solidarity at the EU level.'
The French president added that France would soon be more influential than Britain as the 'the only permanent member of the Security Council to be also a member of the EU when the UK leaves.'
MailOnline has contacted Number 10 for comment.
Polish Prime Minister Beata Szydlo, Theresa May and German Chancellor Angela Merkel
The French president said it was not down to 'the UK or any other 'to represent Europe' for the the US (Mrs May with EU boss Jean Claude Juncker)
